title: Nonvariceal Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding
diagnosis_topic: Peptic ulcer disease causing upper GI bleeding
setup_script: “A 65-year-old man presents with melena and lightheadedness. He takes NSAIDs for chronic knee pain. He denies alcohol use. On arrival, he appears pale and diaphoretic.”

dynamic_flow.reply: “BP 95/60 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 36.9°C; patient pale and diaphoretic.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident secures two large-bore IVs and begins fluid resuscitation
dynamic_flow.reply: “Administer crystalloid followed by transfusion to maintain hemoglobin above 7 g/dL.”
“CBC, coagulation profile, and type & cross are obtained. Hemoglobin 7.6 g/dL, INR 1.2, BUN elevated disproportionately to creatinine.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident starts IV proton pump inhibitor infusion
dynamic_flow.reply: “Esomeprazole bolus followed by continuous infusion is initiated.”
“NG aspirate reveals coffee-ground material confirming an upper GI source.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults gastroenterology for urgent endoscopy
dynamic_flow.reply: “Endoscopy shows a bleeding duodenal ulcer; epinephrine injection and hemoclip achieve hemostasis.”
“Not required in nonvariceal bleeding; patient’s status is unchanged.”
“Patient becomes hypotensive with ongoing melena. What do you want to do next?”
“Bleeding persists despite therapy. Interventional radiology is available for embolization, or operative oversewing may be required.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident tests for Helicobacter pylori
dynamic_flow.reply: “Biopsy is positive for H. pylori. What is your management plan?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident counsels on NSAID cessation and PPI maintenance
dynamic_flow.reply: “NSAIDs are discontinued. Long-term PPI therapy is prescribed.”
“Glasgow–Blatchford score is high, requiring admission and close monitoring.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If patient rebleeds after initial endoscopy
dynamic_flow.reply: “Patient develops melena and tachycardia overnight. Repeat endoscopy shows recurrent bleeding at ulcer site. What is your next step?”
“IR is unable to control the bleeding. The patient continues to bleed with dropping hemoglobin and worsening hypotension. What operative management will you perform?”

critical_decision_points: Recognition and resuscitation of upper GI bleeding with hemodynamic instability
Appropriate use of IV PPI and early endoscopy for diagnosis and therapy
Differentiation between variceal and nonvariceal sources
Management of recurrent bleeding and failed endoscopic therapy
Long-term management including H. pylori eradication and NSAID avoidance
